item.title: General Semantics
item.description: [-@lewis1976general] If we decide to treat objects as semantic interpretant of our names, sets of possible worlds as the semantic interpretant of our sentences, then one-place predicates correspond to functions from objects to sets of possible worlds.

item.title: Incorrigibility as the mark of the mental

item.title: Phenomenalism
item.description: [-@sellars1963phenomenalism]

item.title: Philosophy and the Scientific Image of Man
item.description: [-@sellars1963philosophy] This work distinction between the two images the scientific image: the way the world is specified in the language of Natural Science the manifest image: includes talk about persons includes the use of intentional vocabulary, normative vocabulary and sort of the way people talked every day before the rise of modern mathematized science The principal aim of modern philosophy is to understand and articulate the relation between those images.

item.title: Grammar and Existence
item.description: [-@sellars1960grammar]

item.title: Must We Mean What We Say
item.description: Main question: does what we ordinarily say/mean have a direct+deep control over what we can philosophically say/mean? Goal: respond to objections to the methodology of ‘ordinary language philosophy’ (by Mates) Distinguish 3 kinds of statements about ordinary language * Statements which produce instances of what is said in a language “We do say … but we don’t say …” “We ask whether … but we don’t ask whether …” Like above, but with explications “When we say …, we imply/suggest/say …” “We don’t say … unless we mean …” Generalizations, tested by reference to the first two types Working example: disagreement between Austin and Ryle * Austin: “We say ‘The gift was made voluntarily’ " (type 1) Ryle: “It makes sense… to ask whether a boy was responsible for breaking a window, but not whether he was responsible for finishing his homework in good time” (type 1) Ryle: “‘voluntary’/‘involuntary’ are applied as adjectives to actions which ought not be done” (type 3) Praise of Ryle’s generalization: Philosophical use of “voluntary” is distinct/disconnected from “volition” People think confusedly as if everything is either appropriately described as voluntary or involuntary Criticism of Ryle’s generalization: Saying there must be something morally fishy about the action that is described as voluntary is not general enough.

item.title: Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind
item.description: [-@sellars1956empiricism]

item.title: Some reflections on language games
item.description: [-@sellars1954some] Quotes A rule is always a rule for doing something.

item.title: Philosophical Investigations
item.description: [-@wittgenstein2010philosophical] Private language argument See SEP Quotes about We know the efforts of such philosophers as Frege and Husserl to undo the “psychologizing” of logic (like Kant’s undoing Hume’s psychologizing of knowledge)1: now, the shortest way I might describe such a book as the Philosophical Investigations is to say that it attempts to undo the psychologizing of psychology, to show the necessity controlling our application of psychological and behavioral categories; even, one could say, show the necessities in human action and passion themselves.
Obsidian Vault
title: Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature title: PMN tags: philosophy/person/quinke philosophy/work status/STUB

item.title: -ing vs -ed distinction
item.description: Observed by Sellars to be responsible for a lot of philosophical confusion. Most interesting philosophical concepts come with a “-ing”/ “-ed” distinction that’s crucial to understand the nature of.

item.title: 01 - Historical context and quotes (2009)
item.description: Next Introduction Brandom believes Sellars to be the most important American philosopher of the 20th century. Some ways in which Sellars was remarkable:

item.title: 01 - The Concept of Representation
item.description: Next History of representation Does ‘ representation’ have a nature or a history? Does it belong with “electrons” and “sulfur” or with “freedom” and “the right to vote”?

item.title: 02 - Inference and Meaning and Language Games (2009)
item.description: Prev Next Note on Sellars’ style He preferered the ‘Mystery story’ style: There’s a problem, and many competing potential explanations These explanations engage each other dialectically Only at the end would you learn the philosopher’s actual position In contrast to the ‘Journalistic’ style: Tell them what you’re going to tell them Tell them Tell them what you told them Material inferences Let an inference be a statement with a material conditional, i.

item.title: 02 - Rorty’s Critique of Enlightenment Representationalism and Analytic Philosophy
item.description: Prev Next Rorty’s basic idea Neokantianism vs a socialized/historicized/naturalized alternative Struggle between two camps in the 19th century, which is then re-enacted in the 20th century Neokantianism (Marburg / Freiburg to CI Lewis and Carnap).

item.title: 03 - Language as thought and different species of ought (2009)
item.description: Prev Next Language as thought and communication Sellars wants to give us a naturalistic account of intentionality. Logical behaviorism / philosophical behaviorism

item.title: 03 - Rorty Finds His Pragmatist Voice
item.description: Prev Next Major lessons (From the discussion of truth as “what is best in the way of belief” as opposed to correspondence with reality): How the combination of: declarativism blurring out all distinctions of kind of claimable expressivism a local expressivism about what one is doing in attributing truth — namely not describing the claimable, but endorsing it underwriting a global antirepresentationalism because of special properties of the vocabulary of truth together underwrite a Jamesean understanding of truth-talk.

item.title: 04 - Counterfactuals and the Kant-Sellars Thesis (2009)
item.description: Prev Counterfactuals and dispositions Uses Principia Mathematica notation, which takes some time to learn. Goodman has let the formalism of classical extensional logic mislead him in thinking about counterfactuals.

item.title: 04- Cheryl Misak's Critique of Rorty's Pragmatism
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 05 - Rorty's Literary Turn
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 06 - Rorty's Political Turn
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 07 - Assessing Rorty's Pragmatism as Anti-Representationalism
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 08 - Anti-Representationalism, Pragmatism, and Expressivism
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 09 - Huw Price on Representationalism, Rorty, and Expressivism
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 1. Desire
item.description: We want a theory of desire that can answer questions like: given a scenario and a desire, was that desire satisfied?

item.title: 10 - Simon Blackburn on Expressivism and Pragmatism
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 10. Goodness
item.description: Two notions of good Distinction: good (absolutely) vs good for something vs good E.g. It’s good to be kind, it’s good for me to study math, that’s a good car British 20th centurary moral philosophers like GE Moore don’t like “good for X” wanting a morality that is not egoistic, instead trying to frame in terms of absolute good.

item.title: 11 - Price on Sellars and McDowell, Blackburn on Brandom and McDowell
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 11. Philosophical pictures
item.description: Augustinian picture of how we learn language Wittgenstein opens PI Augustine’s picture: Common sense description: words name objects, sentences are combinations of such names Every word has a correlated meaning which is the object for which the word stands.

item.title: 12 - Price's Pragmatist Philosophy of Language
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 12. Contextualism
item.description: Contexualism concerns the truth of an utterance of depending on factors outside of the statement itself. There is a spectrum of statements one can acknowledge as contexual: At one extreme, statements like “I am cold” The truth is obviously contexually dependent on the speaker of the utterance.

item.title: 13 - Global or Local Expressivism? The Current State of Play
item.description: Prev Next

item.title: 13. Judgment aggregation
item.description: What is it? A formal theory characterizing various ways to combine individual beliefs into collective beliefs What could it mean for a group to have beliefs over and above the beliefs of the individuals?

item.title: 14 - Rationales and Prospects for Anti-Representationalism
item.description: Prev

item.title: 14. Skepticism
item.description: What is radical skepticism advocating? Example: I know there is a table in front of me. (both sides agree that, if I know anything, I at least know that) However, the skeptic rejects that I know there is a table in front of me and therefore rejects that I know anything.

item.title: 15. Religious toleration
item.description: Why tolerate religion? Why protect religious conscience, over and above other forms of moral conscience? Historically, lots of religious intolerance have led to atrocities.

item.title: 16. Justice
item.description: Rawls’ political philosophy “Completing” the contract theory of justice started by Hobbes, developed by Locke / Rousseau / Kant. Most influential modern political philosopher.

item.title: 17. Mechanism and causation
item.description: Action at a distance Action at a distance E.g. Gravity/EM, something in one place can affect something far away without anything passing in between Example Trying to explain how a magic trick (making a match levitate) works.

item.title: 18. Language and power
item.description: This concerns the pragmatics of language Social identities are skills, being a professor/parent is like dribbling a basketball “Calls” Say “Yo, Matt!

item.title: 19. Epistemic vigilance
item.description: Information given to us via testimony vs sense experience There are many situations where we trust and others where we distrust Need to be able to benefit from communication with others.

item.title: 2. Poetry
item.description: What do we mean by poetry Clarification: “poetry” to Plato is more similar to what we call theatre (performative context). Plato thought he innovated the distinction between style and content: Distinguishing the story from the way the poet tells the story E.

item.title: 20. Faith
item.description: Belief when you don’t have overwhelming evidence. Something distinct from knowledge. E.g. Faith in the goodness of humanity. Faith in the resurrection.

item.title: 21. Political liberalism
item.description: What does “liberalism” refer to? Used in such a wide variety of senses that it means almost nothing at all now.

item.title: 22. Collective action
item.description: Can a group of people do an action? We regularly conjoin plural subjects with action verbs. We have a desire to analyze the collective action purely into terms of the individual actions.

item.title: 23. Transcendental arguments
item.description: “How possible” questions General form: X makes Y seem impossible, yet nevertheless Y is possible. Can’t we just reject X because we take Y to be possible, which contradicts taking X seriously?

item.title: 24. Perception of music
item.description: Is hearing emotion in music a purely cultural convention? Distinguish two questions Whether culture has impact on the perceptual states from hearing pieces of music Whether on a particular occasion of hearing music, the perception depends on cultural factors.

item.title: 25. Coversational context
item.description: What does “conversational context” mean? The situation in which a discourse takes place. Not just surrounding material but also the attitudes of the speakers, their interests, the point of what they’re trying to say, etc.

item.title: 26. Evolutionary ethics
item.description: What is altruism? “pure altruism” Help to someone else at some cost to self (distinct from reciprocal altruism: done with expectation of return) Was the tendency to behave altrusitically evolved?

item.title: 3. Nietzsche and Morality
item.description: What does Nietzsche mean by morality? Nietzsche means something different from ethics when using the term morality He presents himself as a “critic of morality” Although also talks about “higher moralities” as things he approves of, using the same German word.

item.title: 34. Moral disagreement
item.description: Moral realism - moral claims are objectively true or false Morals are objects of belief (things out there) E.g. courage is a virtue / justice is a virtue Moral disagreement is possible between individuals and across cultures (no moral relativism in that sense) Question KS is interested: what are the implications of moral reason But moral disagreement makes people think moral realism is false.

item.title: 4. Sexuality and Law
item.description: There has been historical precedent to place legal restrictions on human behavior due to disgust reaction Disgust Rejection of something that is seen as a contaminant (useful in the context of feces, etc.

item.title: 45. Probability
item.description: Conflict between epistemic and objective notions of probability In the former, to express a claim about a coin toss having a 50% chance of being heads is to make a claim about a rational being’s own knowledge, among other things.

item.title: 5. Perception
item.description: What is interesting about perception for philosophers (distinct from biologists/neuroscientists)? Perception has necessary role within analysis of certain concepts Philophers need not come up with a theory of perception Empirical facts about perception may be useful, and the physical theories of perception need not be challenged E.

item.title: 6. Experimental philosophy
item.description: What is it? It’s an alternative source of evidence towards philosophical theses. It’s not always meant to undermine traditional (armchair / mathematical) philosophy.

item.title: 7. Nature and ethics
item.description: Naive way of incorporating the two Something is not acceptable because it is ’not natural'. This has counterexamples in both dimensions (good things - e.

item.title: 8. Evolutionary psychology
item.description: What do they study Study of traits shaped by natural selection No formal distinction from evolutionary biology Example psychological traits/behaviors: jealousy, homicide, male promiscuity What was its evolutionary function of jealousy?

item.title: 9. Metaphor
item.description: Examples of Metaphor What are examples of metaphor? Need to be careful to not use ‘dead metaphors’ idioms “bit the dust” / “went west” / “bought the farm” -> die Metaphors are devices for saying something and using something else Questions philosophers ask There are two lines of questions: Technical ones in the philosophy of language (e.

item.title: A children's game
item.description: From Philosophical Investigations: A mother lets me watch her kids and says to me: “Show the children a game.” When she returns, she sees me teaching them to gamble with dice.

item.title: Against phenomenalism
item.description: To claim that the relationship between the framework of sense contents and that of physical objects can be construed on the phenomalist model (NB: to think of physical objects as constellations of sense contents) is to commit oneself to the idea that there are inductively confirmable generalizations (NB: subjunctive conditionals) about sense contents which are in principle capable of being formulated without the language of physical things.

item.title: Agrippan Trilemma
item.description: It seems like there are only three ways of completing a proof: The circular argument, in which the proof of some proposition presupposes the truth of that very proposition The regressive argument, in which each proof requires a further proof, ad infinitum The dogmatic argument, which rests on accepted precepts which are merely asserted rather than defended These all tend to rub us the wrong way, but this is a problem for classical logic in particular.

item.title: Analytic and synthetic facts
item.description: This intuitive distinction is explained here but is broken in Quine’s Two Dogmas of Empiricism. What is challenged is the very notion of analyticity, i.

item.title: Analytic philosophy
item.description: Often the task of analytic philosophy is to take statements in some potentially-problematic vocabulary and give them an explanation in terms of some preferred or unproblematic vocabulary.

item.title: Analytic vs synthetic statements
item.description: Historically in philosophy, one finds a distinction frequently made between analytic and synthetic statements. We want to put declarative statements into two boxes:

item.description: I wander in from a different culture, into an auction house: There, the significance of waving your hand is bidding the next amount on whatever is being auctioned.

item.title: Baruch Spinoza
item.description: Baruch Spinoza was a Dutch philosopher (1632-1677).

item.title: Bee Waggle
item.description: The bee waggle dance is an empirical phenomenon: when a foraging bee discovers a suppély of food, it returns to the hive and does a waggle dance.

item.title: Behaviorism
item.description: This is related to the problem of: suppose you follow a rule. You use a representation of that rule to train the next generation to follow the rule.

item.title: Bertrand Russell
item.description: TODO

item.title: Bradley's Problem
item.description: Original argument appearring in Chapters II and III of [-@bradley2016appearance}] (originally 1893), and S.E.P. commentary here: Bradley notes that there appears to be such a thing as ‘a lump of sugar’, and this thing appears to have qualities such as whiteness, sweetness, and hardness.

item.title: Brain states and experience
item.description: One can grant there is a causal dependence between brain activity and experience, but it is a leap to suggest that we can identify brain activity with experience.

item.title: Charles Sanders Pierce
item.description: Charles Sanders Pierce Relation to Sellars, habits, and rules For Sellars, the word ‘habit’ denotes a mere regularity. For Pierce, habit is a normative concept.

item.title: Concepts and judgment
item.description: Overview We normally think that the content of judgments are dictated by the content of the concepts used inside of them.

item.title: David Hume
item.description: A Scottish philosopher (1711-1776). Hume’s predicament Even our best understanding of actual observable empirical facts doesn’t yield an understanding of rules relating or otherwise governing them.

item.title: David Lewis

item.title: Definitions
item.description: Miscellaneous definitions. 1 tag:philosophy/def

item.title: Deontology
item.description: TODO

item.title: Depsychologizing
item.description: We know the efforts of such philosophers as Frege and Husserl to undo the “psychologizing” of logic (like Kant’s undoing Hume’s psychologizing of knowledge)1: now, the shortest way I might describe such a book as the Philosophical Investigations is to say that it attempts to undo the psychologizing of psychology, to show the necessity controlling our application of psychological and behavioral categories; even, one could say, show the necessities in human action and passion themselves.

item.title: Describing and explaining
item.description: Although describing and explaining are distinguishable, they are also in an important sense inseparable. The descripitive and explanatory resources of language advance hand-in-hand.

item.title: Describing without modality
item.description: The idea that the world can in principle be so described that the description contains no modal expressions is of a piece with the idea that world can in principle be so described such that the description contains no prescriptive expressions.

item.title: Descriptivism
item.description: Descriptivism is a semantic theory: the belief that what you do with language is describe things. It was an improvement in the philosophy of language which allowed us to avoid the Hesperus Phosphorus puzzle.

item.title: Disjunctivitis
item.description: Suppose someone says “It’s cold outside!” and you want to know if they mean it’s below 40 degrees rather than below 60 degrees.

item.title: Distinctions
item.description: We naturally discretize things in the world into different categories of things, and these distinctions can feel good, like they ‘cut reality at the joints.

item.title: Doxastic modality

item.title: Dualisms
item.description: One way of characterizing dualisms is that they are distinctions which are drawn in such terms that the relation between the distinguished terms becomes unintelligible.

item.title: Duhem-Quine thesis
item.description: It is impossible to test a scientific hypothesis in isolation, because an empirical test of the hypothesis requires one or more background assumptions.

item.title: Ed Witherspoon Argument
item.description: One can grant there is a causal dependence between brain activity and experience, but it is a leap to suggest that we can identify brain activity with experience.

item.title: Edmund Husserl
item.description: TODO

item.title: Elucidations
item.description: Matt Teichman hosts a great podcast, Elucidations, which features ~30 min interviews with philosophy professors about their work. 1 tag:elucidations

item.title: Emotivism
item.description: How can we, in our modern scientific world, come to know moral facts? This is a problem of moral skepticism.

item.title: Empiricism
item.description: Often contrasted with rationalism and naturalism.

item.title: Epistemological skepticism
item.description: There are many flavors, but consider the brain in a vat thought experiment: You are sleeping one night, when the scientist takes out your brain, puts it in a vat, and connects its neurons to a machine that gives/receives electrical inputs such that the brain activity is identical to certain possible real life scenarios if the brain was still in the body.

item.title: Exemplification
item.description: Exemplification is a ‘quasi-semantical’ relation, and it (and universals1) are “in the world” only in that broad sense in which the ‘world’ includes linguistic norms and roles viewed (thus in translating) from the standpoint of a fellow participant.

item.title: Experience and Nature
item.description: [-@dewey1958experience]

item.title: Expressions as explanations
item.description: To make firsthand use of modal expressions / subjunctive conditionals, is to be about the business of explaining a state of affairs or justifying an assertion.

item.title: Frederich Nietzsche
item.description: A German philosopher (1844-1900). Quotes Mobile army Truth is a mobile army of metaphors, metonyms, anthropomorphisms, in short, a sum of human relations which were poetically and rhetorically heightened, transferred, and adorned, and after long use seem solid, canonical, and binding to a nation.

item.description: George Berkeley was a philosopher.

item.title: Goal of philosophy
item.description: The aim of philosophy is to understand how things, in the broadest possible sense of the term, hang together, in the broadest possible sense of the term.

item.description: A German metaphysical [rationalism|rationalist].

item.title: Having a nature or a history
item.description: When introduced to a new concept, do you prefer to be given a definition for it in terms of other concepts, or do you prefer a story of how the word came to be used as it’s used?

item.title: Hesperus and Phosphorus
item.description: From Wikipedia These are puzzles posed by Frege. They are addressed by making a distinction between sense and reference. First puzzle The brightest star in morning was called Hesperus, and the brightest star of evening was called Phosphorus.

item.title: Huw Price
item.description: Huw Price is an Australian philosopher, born 1953.

item.title: Immanuel Kant
item.description: Immanuel Kant was a German philosopher (1724-1804). On Locke The “celebrated Mr. Locke” (i.e. empiricism) offered “a mere physiology of the understanding.

item.description: [-@sellars1953inference]

item.title: Infinite regresses
item.description: A common kind of problem. 1 tag:philosophy/problem/regress

item.title: Instrumentalism
item.description: All of our evidence in science comes from empirical observation, so all of our concepts (and claims) must be translatable without remainder into observational vocabulary.

item.title: Is-ought problem
item.description: The is-ought problem. David Hume. The infeasibility of reducing “ought talk” to “is talk” is the same problem (according to Sellars) as reducing “the personal” (e.

item.title: Jaques Derrida
item.description: A French philosopher (1930-2005). Philosophers have had this idea that reason is central to talk and thought. But we hardly ever actually reason with each other or argue or infer; look at all the playful things we can do with language.

item.title: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
item.description: Quotes “Obedience to a law that one has laid oneself is freedom.”

item.title: Jerry Fodor
item.description: Jerry Alan Fodor was an American philosopher in the fields of philosophy of mind and cognitive science. (1935-2017) He is called an atomist about representation by Brandom when he talks about the relation between ‘horses’ and horses.

item.title: John Dewey
item.description: John Dewey was an American pragmatist philosopher, 1959-1952. Rorty on Dewey Dewey wants the distinctions between science and philosophy to be rubbed out and replaced with an uncontroversial notion of intelligence trying to solve problems and provide meanings.

item.title: John Locke
item.description: John Locke was an English philospher (1632-1704).

item.title: John Stuart Mill
item.description: John Stuart Mill

item.title: Judgment in the order of explanation
item.description: Kant was on the right track when he insisted that, just as concepts are essentially (not accidentally) items which can occur in judgments, so judgments (and therefore indirectly concepts) are items that occur essentially (not accidentally) that occur in reasonings or arguments.

item.title: Kant-Sellars thesis
item.description: From three premises: what you need to move from labeling to describing is situation in a space of implications space of implications must draw lines between implications that will between counterfactual circumstances under which the implication would still be good, and those in which wouldn’t the expressive job, not in the first instance, a descriptive job that’s characteristic of modal vocabulary is to make explicit those range those implications and those ranges of counterfactual robustness Put another way, suppose Sellars is right that modal expressions function as inference licenses.

item.title: Kantian Lessons about Mind, Meaning, and Rationality
item.description: [-@brandom2006kantian]

item.title: Labels vs describing
item.description: It’s only because the expressions in terms of which we describe objects, locate those objects in a space of implications that they describe it all rather than merely label.

item.title: Labels vs descriptions
item.description: It’s only because the expressions in terms of which we describe objects, locate those objects in a space of implications that they describe it all rather than merely label.

item.title: Language, Rules and Behavior
item.description: [-@sellars1950language]

item.title: Law of the excluded middle
item.description: TODO

item.title: Left and right wing Sellarsians
item.description: Rorty characterized the followers of Sellars as being left or right wing depending on which passage was found to be more insightful/fundamental to Sellars’ thought.

item.title: Lost Keys
item.description: One night, a drunk man is searching on the ground under a streetlight. An officer approaches and asks “What are you looking for?

item.title: Ludwig Wittgenstein
item.description: An Austrian philosopher (1889-1951). Quotes Language has no downtown A view attributed to Wittgenstein by Brandom: “Language has no downtown.” / “Language is a motley”

item.title: Man as rational animal
item.description: To say that man is a rational animal is to say that man is a creature not of habits but of rules.

item.title: Martin Heidegger
item.description: Martin Heidegger was a German philosopher (1889-1976).

item.title: Material conditional
item.description: In logic, we see expressions like $P \implies Q$ a lot. The symbol $\implies$ is read as ‘implies’ and is also called the material conditional.

item.title: Material inference vs logical inference
item.description: Let an inference be a statement with a material conditional, i.e. of the form “If $P$, then $Q$”1 in a language with ordinary statements as well as logical connectives (e.

item.title: Meaning and truth
item.description: Tarski’s theory of truth says: if you take meanings for granted, I can give you a truth predicate. Davidson flipped this on its head, saying: Tarski provided the meanings of a class of terms given how they interact with other propositions.

item.title: Michael Dummett
item.description: Michael Dummett was an English philosopher of logic (1925-2011).

item.title: Mind and World
item.description: TODO

item.title: Mind-body dualism
item.description: Descartes had invented representation but came to think of things things in the world to be divided into representeds (things) and representings (ideas).

item.title: Montaigne's dog
item.description: Montaigne is impressed that his dog, when chasing a rabbit and coming to a fork, runs a little way down one of the paths and smells no rabbit, then immediately runs down the other fork of the path without stopping to smell to check if the rabbit went that way.

item.title: Myth of the Given
item.description: To do A (semantic) holist argument against meaning-givenness, like Quines’ Myth of the Museum against sense-givenness.

item.title: Myth of the Museum
item.description: Uncritical semantics is the myth of a museum in which the exhibits are meanings and the words are labels. To switch languages is to change the labels.

item.title: Naming and Saying
item.description: [-@sellars1962naming]

item.title: Naturalism
item.description: TODO

item.title: Nelson Goodman
item.description: TODO

item.title: Nondescriptive concepts
item.description: Once the tautology ’the world is described by descriptive concepts’ is freed from the idea that the business of all non-logical concepts is to describe, the way is clear to an ungrudging recognition that many expressions which empiricists have relegated to second-class citizenship in discourse are not inferior, they’re just different.

item.title: Nonmonotonic logic
item.description: TODO

item.title: Norm-fact dualism
item.description: A problem for those who try to address the problem of Cartesian dualism by appealing to the normative character of intentionality.

item.title: Noumena and phenomena
item.description: In the eyes of Hegel/Sellars/Brandom, Kant is interpreted as having radicalized the distinction between: primary qualities (properties that are truly there) secondary qualities (properties that are due to us).

item.title: Novel sentences
item.description: We can sometimes underestimate the generativity of language and its radical novelty. Consider something as easy to understand as “For the picnic today, I hope you packed all the sandwiches we made last night and the baseball gear.

item.title: Objective and subjective facts
item.description: So, a second characterization of pragmatism might go like this: there is no epistemological difference between truth about what ought to be and truth about what is, nor any metaphysical difference between facts and values, nor any methodological difference between morality and science.

item.title: On community
item.description: To say that a person desired to do A, thought it his duty to do B, but was forced to do C, is not to describe him as one might describe a scientific specimen.

item.title: Ontological and deontological matters
item.description: Ordinarily we think of the ontological and the deontological as being very different, easily distinguishable kinds of things. However, Sellars’ quote

item.title: Ontology
item.description: The theory of what really is, or the what is there ‘objectively’.

item.title: Ontology and grammar
item.description: Ontological categories are the material mode of speech for syntactical categories. — Grammar and Existence

item.title: Ought to be vs ought to do
item.description: Ought to do’s Ought to be’s Rule of action Rule of reflection If you’re in circumstances $C$, do $A$ Pattern based judgment Conceptually articulated Not necessarily conceptually articulated Rules of deliberation Rule of assessment/criticism First personal Third personal judgment of some behavior What’s appropriate for me to do?

item.title: Phenomenology of Spirit

item.title: Philosophical Problems
item.description: This chapter is a collection of situations that are brought up as problems to be solved by various philosophers. 1 tag:philosophy/problem

item.title: Philosophical situations
item.description: Philosophical ‘situations’ is a very ambiguous category of anecdotes. They’re descriptions of the world (hypothetical or realistic) that can be seen as problems in their own right, or counter-examples to some commonplace theories, or evidence in favor of a particular theory, etc.

item.title: Pia's Maple Tree
item.description: Example from Charles Travis @{wright1997companion} (Pragmatics, pg 97): Maple trees have red leaves naturally, but Pia paints them green. One day, a decorator asks her if she has any green leaves for her display, and Pia answers yes.

item.title: Plato
item.description: Plato was an ancient Greek philosopher (428 BC - 348 BC).

item.title: Pluto
item.description: Example from Brandom writing about Sellars. Pluto was first postulated in order to explain perturbations in the orbit of Neptune (by inference from Newton’s laws).

item.title: Pointing at a plate
item.description: We think it’s straightforward when a teacher points to a plate and says ‘plate’. However, one might argue the teacher has also pointed to:

item.title: Pragmatism
item.description: Overview TODO Example semantics What does it mean that “All $A$’s are necessarily $B$’s”? A pragmatist answer is that it is a license to infer statements like “$x$ is a $B$” from statements like “$x$ is an $A$”.

item.title: Rationalism
item.description: Often contrasted with empiricism.

item.title: Referring to witches
item.description: Jones says “The witch who lives in the house at the end of the street really scares me.” We, not believing in the myth of witches, can have a couple of reactions to this:

item.title: Regress of rules
item.description: To follow a rule (e.g. ‘under circumstances $C$, do $A$’, or ‘Whenever you see a cat, raise your arm’), we have to understand the concepts that are involved within (i.

item.title: René Descartes
item.description: René Descartes was a French mathematician, scientist, and philosopher: 1596–1650.

item.title: Representation
item.description: Representation is a theory of the relation between appearance and reality. A successor notion to theories of resemblance Premodern theories understood relation between appearance and reality in terms of resemblance (sharing properties)

item.title: Representation regress
item.description: If any things are known representationally, then some things must be known nonrepresentationally (immediately, by being had or grasped). Otherwise we can’t know about something via a representation $R$, because we’d need another representation to know $R$.

item.title: Representationalism
item.description: TODO

item.title: Richard Rorty
item.description: An American philosopher, 1931-2007. Remark (in conversation) Nothing of any philosophical significance has ever happened within 6 feet in any direction of a quantifier symbol

item.title: Rigid designator
item.description: Kripke’s theory of the meaning of names (from Naming and Necessity) that is alternative to descriptivism: A name refers to the same object in all possible worlds in which that object exists, and the name never refers to anything else.

item.title: Robert Brandom
item.description: An American philosopher, born in 1950. Links Academic website Lectures Antirepresentationalism (2020) Wilfrid Sellars (2009) (2019) Slogans Concepts It’s not about our grip on concepts1; it’s about the concept’s grip on us.

item.title: Rudolf Carnap
item.description: Rudolf Carnap was a German philosopher, 1891-1970. Called an atomist about representation by Brandom.

item.title: Rules are lived
item.description: A rule, properly speaking, isn’t a rule unless it lives in behavior, rule-regulated behavior. Even rule-violating behavior. Linguistically we always operate within a framework of living rules.

item.title: Ruth Millikan
item.description: An example of a right-wing Sellarsian.

item.title: Saul Kripke

item.title: Schools of thought
item.description: 1 tag:philosophy/school

item.title: Scienta mensura
item.description: In the dimension of describing and explaining the world, science is the measure of all of things. Of what is that it is, and of what is not that it is not.

item.title: Sellars Lecture 1 (2019)
item.description: Sellars is a great philosopher. This is what that means to Brandom: the work being transformative when you understand it, you then view many other central problems in philosophy differently) deep as in radical, going to the roots Not necessary influential (e.

item.title: Semantic skepticism
item.description: A Kantian insight: the real problematic skepticism is semantic skepticism. He doesn’t take it for granted that we can ‘represent’ reality and merely have to worry about whether or not that representation is true.

item.title: Semantics
item.description: Empiricism An empiricist approach to semantics wants to give semantics of an expression in terms of its sense dependence rather than its reference dependence.

item.title: Sense data and concepts
item.description: It feels natural to try to reduce concepts to combinations of sense impressions (this is what Locke/Hume do). This is a mistake that comes from the fact that sense impressions are causally prior to our concepts.

item.title: Sense dependence vs reference
item.description: Two meanings of “$X$ depends on $Y$” that are easily conflated. Kind of reference Sense Reference Meaning of $X$ depends on $Y$ you can’t understand $X$ unless you understand $Y$ you can’t have $X$ existing without $Y$ existing Flavor of dependence Epistemological Ontological Robert Brandom points out that we can have sense dependence without having reference dependence.

item.title: Sense vs reference
item.description: The distinction between sense and reference is attributed to Frege.

item.title: Shopping list
item.description: From [-@anscombe2000intention] A man has arrived at the grocery store to go shopping, but realizes he’s forgotten his shopping list. Unbenknownst to him, a spy is following him tasked with writing a list of everything that is put into the grocery cart.

item.title: Skepticism
item.description: Skepticism comes in many flavors. 1 tag:skepticism

item.title: Sour acid
item.description: Historically we might have had at some point the following theory of acids: “Anything that’s sour is an acid. And anything that’s an acid will turn litmus paper red.

item.title: Space of reasons
item.description: In characterizing an episode or a state as knowing, we are not giving an empirical description of it. We are placing it in the logical space of reasons, of justifying and being able to justify what one says.

item.title: Stanley Cavell
item.description: Stanley Cavell was an American philosopher (1926-2018).

item.title: Subjunctive conditionals as essential
item.description: We’ve established not only that subjunctive conditionals are the expressions of material rules of inference, but that the authority of those rules is not derivative from formal rules.

item.title: Subjunctive vs counterfactual conditionals
item.description: Subjunctive conditional: if $X$ were $\psi$’d, it would $\phi$. Counterfactual conditional: if $X$ had been $\psi$’d, it would have $\phi$’d.

item.title: Switcharoos
item.description: Often there are ideas that are closely related, and it becomes ambiguous which idea is ‘first’, if any. 1 tag:philosophy/switcharoo

item.title: Teleosemantics
item.description: Developed by Ruth Millikan. A simple example: imagine that beavers slap their tail when there’s danger, and beavers flee when they hear another beaver slap its tail.

item.title: The Blue and Brown books
item.description: [-@wittgenstein1958blue] What is … questions The questions: “What is length?” “What is meaning?” “What is the number one?” etc. produce in us a mental cramp.

item.title: The Frege-Geach problem
item.description: A problem for people who subscribe to emotivism. Also sometimes called the embedding problem. Theories in the noncognitivist tradition share the view that the distinctive meaning of moral words does not concern what they are about, and it either does not require or is not exhausted by any answer to what makes moral sentences true.

item.title: The War Hero
item.description: From [-@castaneda1968logic]: A man serves in a WWII. In a battle, he does something extremely heroicly, and lots of people see.

item.title: Theoretical and observable objects
item.description: It is commonly reasoned that abstract or theoretical objects and concrete observable objects are simply different types of things. The example of Pluto makes it clear that what we really want to make is a distinction of how we come to know of something, rather than thinking about ontological different things.

item.title: Theoretical vs obserable objects - Pluto
item.description: … according to Sellars’s view, the distinction between theoretical objects and observable objects is methodological, rather than ontological. That is, theoretical and observable objects are not different kinds of thing.

item.title: Tooth pain
item.description: From [-@brandom2019some]: Imagine a community that talked about having gold or silver in one’s teeth Later, the community extends that practice to talk about having pain in one’s teeth.

item.title: Transition to conceptual thinking
item.description: Anything which can properly be called ‘conceptual thinking’ can occur only within a framework of conceptual thinking in terms of which it can be criticized, supported, refuted (in short, evaluated).

item.title: Transposed langauge of norms
item.description: The language of modalities is … a “transposed” language of norms. … Modal terms, normative terms and psychological terms are mutually irreducible.

item.title: Universals
item.description: It seems there is no problem thinking about what triangles and white things are, but what of triangularity and whiteness?

item.title: W.O. Quine
item.description: W.O. Quine was an American philosopher (1908–2000).

item.title: What the Tortoise said to Achilles
item.description: By Lewis Caroll in 1895. [-@carroll2021tortoise] Summary The Tortoise assumes a proposition $p$ and a material conditional $p \implies q$.

item.title: Wilfrid Sellars
item.description: Born 1912 in Michigan, died in 1989.
